title: Thyssen-Krupp Climbs as German Steel Group Speeds Up CEO Ousting and Sticks With Elevator Sale
text:
Text size

German industrial conglomerate Thyssen-Krupp ’s stock rose after speeding up the process of removing its chief executive and sticking to plans to sell its elevator business.

The stock climbed 2.8% on Friday as the conglomerate replaced Guido Kerkhoff after 14 months in charge.

The back story.

The struggling German steel-to-submarines conglomerate intends to merge its steel division with Tata Steel and split the rest of the company into two, following pressure from activist investors Cevian Capital and Elliott Management.

Activist investors have been pushing large German conglomerates, such as Siemens , to break up and sell or float non-core divisions to maximize shareholder value.

in May Thyssen-Krupp abandoned the move, three years in the making, due to EU regulatory opposition and the low level of its share price, instead revealing plans to list its elevator business, before later agreeing to consider a sale.

Despite shares climbing 28% on the lift announcement, the company returned to crisis earlier this week after sayint it was preparing to replace CEO Guido Kerkhoff with current chairwoman Martina Merzafter after just 14 months in charge, .

The company issued four profit warnings during Kerkhoff’s reign as weaker demand from carmakers, global trade tensions and higher steel prices hit performance.

Shares recovered from 16-year lows in August after the company formalized its turnaround plan, but investors seemed to have lost faith in Kerkhoff’s capacity to carry it out.

What’s new.

Thyssen-Krupp sped up the process of removing Kerkhoff on Friday, after Carten Spohr, the chief executive of Lufthansa , the German airline, gave up his seat on the conglomerate’s supervisory board.

Spohr’s resignation allows Merz, a member of the Lufthansa board, to take over as Thyssen-Krupp CEO without the risk of cross-link, the company explained.

Investors welcomed the acceleration as shares continued to rise, jumping 2.7% in early trading.

Merz is set to become the interim chief executive for up a year, while the German group hunts for a permanent successor to Kerkhoff.

Moving forward.

The removal of Kerkhoff ends a turbulent 14 months for the company and its share price.

Crucially Thyssen-Krupp said the chief executive’s departure would not bring about any changes to its plans for the elevator business.

Investors have welcomed the plan to sell or list the elevator unit, which should lift the stock higher.
description: German industrial conglomerate Thyssen-Krupp has climbed after speeding up the process of removing its chief executive and sticking to plans to sell its elevator business.
